sn17.35:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
sn17.35:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
sn17.35:1.1.comm: This discourse is also at AN 4.68; the verse is at SN 6.12. This Sutta and the next (with sequence reversed) form part of the full story of Devadatta in the Vinaya (Kd 17:2.1.21.

sn17.35:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā devadattaṃ ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn17.35:1.2.eng: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:

sn17.35:1.3.pli: “attavadhāya, bhikkhave, devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.
sn17.35:1.3.eng: “Possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.

sn17.35:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kadalī attavadhāya phalaṃ deti, parābhavāya phalaṃ deti;

sn17.35:2.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.

sn17.35:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, veḷu attavadhāya phalaṃ deti, parābhavāya phalaṃ deti;

sn17.35:3.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.

sn17.35:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, naḷo attavadhāya phalaṃ deti, parābhavāya phalaṃ deti;
sn17.35:4.1.eng: or a reed, all of which bear fruit to their own ruin and downfall …

sn17.35:4.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.

sn17.35:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, assatarī attavadhāya gabbhaṃ gaṇhāti, parābhavāya gabbhaṃ gaṇhāti;
sn17.35:5.1.eng: It’s like a mule, which becomes pregnant to its own ruin and downfall.

sn17.35:5.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.
sn17.35:5.2.eng: In the same way, possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.

sn17.35:5.3.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.35:6.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn17.35:6.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn17.35:6.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn17.35:7.1.eng: “The banana plant is destroyed by its own fruit,

sn17.35:7.2.eng: as are the bamboo and the reed.

sn17.36:1.1.eng: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn17.36:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena devadattassa ajātasattukumāro pañcahi rathasatehi sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ gacchati, pañca ca thālipākasatāni bhattābhihāro abhiharīyati.
sn17.36:1.2.eng: Now at that time Prince Ajātasattu was going with five hundred carts at daybreak and dusk to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food.

sn17.36:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn17.36:1.3.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn17.36:1.4.pli: “devadattassa, bhante, ajātasattukumāro pañcahi rathasatehi sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ gacchati, pañca ca thālipākasatāni bhattābhihāro abhiharīyatī”ti.
sn17.36:1.4.eng: “Sir, Prince Ajātasattu is going with five hundred carts at daybreak and dusk to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food.”

sn17.36:1.5.eng: “Mendicants, don’t envy Devadatta’s possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.36:1.6.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, devadattassa ajātasattukumāro pañcahi rathasatehi sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ gamissati, pañca ca thālipākasatāni bhattābhihāro āharīyissati, hāniyeva, bhikkhave, devadattassa pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no vuddhi.
sn17.36:1.6.eng: As long as Prince Ajātasattu goes with five hundred carts at daybreak and dusk to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food, Devadatta can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities.

sn17.36:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, caṇḍassa kukkurassa nāsāya pittaṃ bhindeyyuṃ, evañhi so, bhikkhave, kukkuro bhiyyoso mattāya caṇḍataro assa;
sn17.36:2.1.eng: If they were to lance a boil on a wild dog’s nose, it would get even wilder.
sn17.36:2.1.comm: Read pitta as “swelling” (from √pīṇ) rather than “bile”. Cf. Sanskrit piḍaka, “a small boil, pustule, or pimple”.

sn17.36:2.2.pli: evameva, bhikkhave, yāvakīvañca devadattassa ajātasattukumāro pañcahi rathasatehi sāyaṃ pātaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ gamissati, pañca ca thālipākasatāni bhattābhihāro āharīyissati, hāniyeva, bhikkhave, devadattassa pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no vuddhi.
sn17.36:2.2.eng: In the same way, as long as Prince Ajātasattu goes with five hundred carts at daybreak and dusk to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food, Devadatta can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities.

sn17.36:2.3.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.37:1.2.pli: “Dāruṇo, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.37:1.2.eng: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are grim, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.37:1.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
sn17.37:1.3.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

sn17.37:1.4.eng: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of their mother.’

sn17.37:1.5.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsantaṃ.
sn17.37:1.5.eng: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.37:1.6.pli: Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.37:1.6.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.37:1.7.eng: So you should train like this:

sn17.37:1.8.eng: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’

sn17.37:1.9.pli: Na ca no uppanno lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.

sn17.38-43:1.2.pli: “Dāruṇo, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.38-43:1.2.eng: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are grim, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.38-43:1.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
sn17.38-43:1.3.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

sn17.38-43:1.4.eng: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of their father.’ …”

sn17.38-43:1.11.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsantaṃ.
sn17.38-43:1.11.eng: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.38-43:1.12.pli: Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.38-43:1.12.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.38-43:1.13.eng: So you should train like this:

sn17.38-43:1.14.pli: ‘uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ pajahissāma, na ca no uppanno lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
sn17.38-43:1.14.eng: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’

sn17.38-43:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on possessions, honor, and popularity are complete.

sn17.4:1.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dīghalomikā eḷakā kaṇṭakagahanaṃ paviseyya.
sn17.4:1.3.eng: Suppose a fleecy sheep was to enter a briar patch.

sn17.4:1.4.pli: Sā tatra tatra sajjeyya, tatra tatra gayheyya, tatra tatra bajjheyya, tatra tatra anayabyasanaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn17.4:1.4.eng: She’d get caught, snagged, and trapped at every turn, coming to ruin.

sn17.4:1.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati.
sn17.4:1.5.eng: In the same way, take a certain mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter the village or town for alms.

sn17.4:1.6.pli: So tatra tatra sajjati, tatra tatra gayhati, tatra tatra bajjhati, tatra tatra anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati.
sn17.4:1.6.eng: They get caught, snagged, and trapped at every turn, coming to ruin.

sn17.4:1.7.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.5:1.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mīḷhakā gūthādī gūthapūrā puṇṇā gūthassa. Purato cassa mahāgūthapuñjo.
sn17.5:1.3.eng: Suppose there was a dung-eating beetle full of dung, stuffed with dung, and before her was a huge pile of dung.

sn17.5:1.4.eng: She’d look down on other beetles, thinking:

sn17.5:1.5.pli: ‘ahamhi gūthādī gūthapūrā puṇṇā gūthassa, purato ca myāyaṃ mahāgūthapuñjo’ti.
sn17.5:1.5.eng: ‘For I am a dung-eating beetle full of dung, stuffed with dung, and before me is a huge pile of dung.’

sn17.5:1.6.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati.
sn17.5:1.6.eng: In the same way, take a certain mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter the village or town for alms.

sn17.5:1.7.pli: So tattha bhuttāvī ca hoti yāvadattho, nimantito ca svātanāya, piṇḍapāto cassa pūro.
sn17.5:1.7.eng: There they eat as much as they like, get invited back tomorrow, and have plenty of almsfood.

sn17.5:1.8.pli: So ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhugaṇassa majjhe vikatthati:
sn17.5:1.8.eng: When they get back to the monastery, they boast in the middle of a group of mendicants:

sn17.5:1.9.pli: ‘bhuttāvī camhi yāvadattho, nimantito camhi svātanāya, piṇḍapāto ca myāyaṃ pūro, lābhī camhi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ, ime panaññe bhikkhū appapuññā appesakkhā na lābhino cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānan’ti.
sn17.5:1.9.eng: ‘I ate as much as I liked, got invited back tomorrow, and had plenty of almsfood. I get robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. But these other mendicants have little merit or significance, so they don’t get these things.’

sn17.5:1.10.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto aññe pesale bhikkhū atimaññati.
sn17.5:1.10.eng: With a mind overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity, they look down on other good-hearted mendicants.

sn17.5:1.11.pli: Tañhi tassa, bhikkhave, moghapurisassa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
sn17.5:1.11.eng: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.

sn17.5:1.12.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.6:1.3.pli: Kaṃ, bhikkhave, asanivicakkaṃ āgacchatu, sekhaṃ appattamānasaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko anupāpuṇātu.
sn17.6:1.3.eng: Let forked lightning fall on whom? Let possessions, honor, and popularity come to a trainee who has not achieved their heart’s desire.
sn17.6:1.3.comm: The phrasing here is odd, but the regular syntax in the two phrases (object in accusative, subject in nominative, verb in imperative), as well as the parallel phrasing in the next Sutta, argue against it being corrupt (as posited by Bodhi). I think the Buddha is quoting a curse, then he substitutes the Dhammic meaning. Compare Atharva Veda 8.4.20: “Let Indra hurl his lightning at the sorcerers!”, where Sanskrit aśani = Pali asani (“lightning-bolt”). See the next Sutta and note. | For asanivicakka (“forked lightning”) see Rig Veda 4.35.2, where vicakra means “divided”. This phrase is only used in one other place in the canon, which is also about a decadent monk (DN 25:11.3).

sn17.6:2.1.eng: ‘Forked lightning’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.6:2.2.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.7:1.3.pli: Kaṃ, bhikkhave, diddhagatena visallena sallena vijjhatu, sekhaṃ appattamānasaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko anupāpuṇātu.
sn17.7:1.3.eng: Let whom be pierced by a poisoned arrow? Let possessions, honor, and popularity come to a trainee who has not achieved their heart’s desire.
sn17.7:1.3.comm: The construction parallels the previous (except the opening sentence is passive). Again, I think the Buddha is quoting a well-known curse. Compare Atharva Veda 8.3.6, where Agni is called on to smear poison on his arrow-tip and loose it at the sorcerers. Pali salla = Sanskrit śalya (“arrow”), while Pali diddha = Sanskrit dih (“smear with poison”). Thus these two adjacent Suttas reinterpret curses in adjacent sections of the Atharva Veda that invoke Indra and Agni, the two most powerful Vedic gods.

sn17.7:2.1.eng: ‘Arrow’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.7:2.2.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.8:1.3.pli: Assuttha no tumhe, bhikkhave, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ jarasiṅgālassa vassamānassā”ti?
sn17.8:1.3.eng: Mendicants, did you hear an old jackal howling at the crack of dawn?”

sn17.8:1.5.pli: “Eso kho, bhikkhave, jarasiṅgālo ukkaṇḍakena nāma rogajātena phuṭṭho neva bilagato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati;
sn17.8:1.5.eng: “That old jackal has the disease called mange. He’s not happy in his den, or at the root of a tree, or out in the open.

sn17.8:1.6.pli: yena yena gacchati, yattha yattha tiṭṭhati, yattha yattha nisīdati, yattha yattha nipajjati; tattha tattha anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati.
sn17.8:1.6.eng: Wherever he goes, stands, sits, or lies down he meets with tragedy and disaster.

sn17.8:1.7.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto neva suññāgāragato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati;
sn17.8:1.7.eng: In the same way, take a certain mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They’re not happy in an empty hut, at the root of a tree, or out in the open.

sn17.8:1.8.pli: yena yena gacchati, yattha yattha tiṭṭhati, yattha yattha nisīdati, yattha yattha nipajjati; tattha tattha anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati.
sn17.8:1.8.eng: Wherever they go, stand, sit, or lie down they meet with tragedy and disaster.

sn17.8:1.9.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.9:1.3.pli: Upari, bhikkhave, ākāse verambhā nāma vātā vāyanti.
sn17.9:1.3.eng: High in the atmosphere there are gale-force winds blowing.

sn17.9:1.4.pli: Tattha yo pakkhī gacchati tamenaṃ verambhā vātā khipanti.
sn17.9:1.4.eng: Any bird that flies there is flung about by those gale-force winds.

sn17.9:1.5.pli: Tassa verambhavātakkhittassa aññeneva pādā gacchanti, aññena pakkhā gacchanti, aññena sīsaṃ gacchati, aññena kāyo gacchati.
sn17.9:1.5.eng: Their feet go one way, their wings another, their head another, and their body another.

sn17.9:1.6.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya arakkhitena cittena, anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā, asaṃvutehi indriyehi.
sn17.9:1.6.eng: In the same way, take a certain monk whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. He robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters the village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.

sn17.9:1.7.pli: So tattha passati mātugāmaṃ dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā.
sn17.9:1.7.eng: There he sees a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.

sn17.9:1.8.pli: Tassa mātugāmaṃ disvā dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.

sn17.9:1.9.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
sn17.9:1.9.eng: He disavows the training and returns to a lesser life.

sn17.9:1.10.pli: Tassa aññe cīvaraṃ haranti, aññe pattaṃ haranti, aññe nisīdanaṃ haranti, aññe sūcigharaṃ haranti, verambhavātakkhittasseva sakuṇassa.
sn17.9:1.10.eng: Some take his robe, others his bowl, others his sitting cloth, others his needle case, just like the bird flung about by the gale-force winds.

sn17.9:1.11.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn18.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn18.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn18.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn18.1:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn18.1:1.3.comm: Rāhula was the Buddha’s son to his wife Bhaddakaccānā (AN 1.245). Rāhula’s going forth is related at Kd 1:54.1.1, and other important discourses with him include MN 61, MN 62, and MN 147 = SN 35.121. In the latter he became an arahant, which he confirmed in his own words at Thag 4.8. Commentaries explain his name as meaning “bondage”, but it probably refers rather to being born under the influence of the dark star Rāhu (SN 2.8). The Buddha declared him the foremost of monks who desire training (AN 1.209). This is illustrated in this series of lessons through which Rāhula doggedly persists. His death is not noted in the early texts.

sn18.1:1.4.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn18.1:1.4.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn18.1:2.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.1:2.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn18.1:2.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn18.1:2.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn18.1:2.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn18.1:2.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn18.1:3.11.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn18.1:3.11.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn18.1:3.13.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn18.1:3.13.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn18.1:3.14.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn18.1:4.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati …pe… sotasmimpi nibbindati … ghānasmimpi nibbindati … jivhāyapi nibbindati … kāyasmimpi nibbindati … manasmimpi nibbindati;
sn18.1:4.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, the ear, the nose, the tongue, the body, and the mind.
sn18.1:4.1.comm: In this and similar passages, Mahāsaṅgīti edition inserts unnecessary ellipses.

sn18.1:4.2.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn18.1:4.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn18.1:4.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn18.1:4.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn18.1:4.4.eng: (The ten discourses of this series should be told in full the same way.)

sn18.10:1.10.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati …pe… vedanāyapi nibbindati … saññāyapi nibbindati … saṅkhāresupi nibbindati … viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
sn18.10:1.10.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn18.10:1.11.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn18.10:1.11.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn18.10:1.12.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn18.10:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn18.11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.

sn18.11:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn18.11:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn18.11:1.5.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.11:1.7.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn18.11:1.7.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn18.11:1.9.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn18.11:1.9.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn18.11:1.10.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn18.11:1.16.eng: Is the mind permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.11:1.18.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn18.11:1.18.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn18.11:1.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn18.11:1.20.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn18.11:1.21.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn18.11:1.23.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati …pe… sotasmimpi nibbindati … ghānasmimpi nibbindati … jivhāyapi nibbindati … kāyasmimpi nibbindati … manasmimpi nibbindati;
sn18.11:1.23.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, the ear, the nose, the tongue, the body, and the mind.

sn18.11:1.24.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn18.11:1.24.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn18.11:1.25.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn18.11:1.25.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn18.11:1.26.eng: (The ten discourses of this series should be told in full the same way.)
